We follow a mean-looking alley cat to the front of a modest, ground-floor apartment. It pauses, then slinks round the side, onto a ledge and in through a partially-opened window. INT.    MARK'S PLACE.    NIGHT 3                                                                     3 The cat comes through the window, hops onto the floor and quickly finds a nice little plate of food scraps that has been set out specially. As it settles down to its meal, we become aware of a heavy and regular sound, like a ship's pump, coming from somewhere close-by. In the center of the room is an object that looks like a prop from a `50s sci-fi movie. A human head protrudes from one end. The object is an iron lung, and its purpose is to keep its occupant, Mark O'Brien, breathing. Every 4.5 seconds, the pump mechanism creates a vacuum inside, forcing Mark's chest to expand and suck in air. He is fast asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Breathing Look you This most excellent canopy, the air, Presses down upon me At 15 pounds per square inch A dense, heavy, blue-glowing ocean. Teasing me with its nearness and immensity. And all I get is a thin stream of it. A finger's width of the rope that ties me to life. Having now eaten its fill, the cat has a good scratch, then wanders over to the iron lung.

direction.raw_text: Yes, that would count.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like me to visit you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you married?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have a steady boyfriend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then please visit as often as you can. EXT.   HOSPITAL.   DAY 160                                                     160 She smiles. Mark is loaded into an ambulance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bye. Take care.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's just one more thing I want to tell you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets into the ambulance and squats down next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not a virgin. She looks genuinely pleased to hear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, are you in a relationship at the moment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it was a passing thing. The driver is ready to shut the doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for sharing that with me. She gets out of the ambulance and waves. INT.   AMBULANCE.     DAY 161                                                               161 Mark is accompanied by an AMBULANCE OFFICER. We see clear blue sky through the back windows. The sun shines in and warms Mark's face. He closes his eyes in contentment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice day, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The best.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good to be alive, huh? EXT. HOSPITAL.      DAY 162                                                               162 We see the disappearing figure of Susan from the point of view of the departing ambulance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I met Susan five years before I died. She was the love of my life. We had the same priorities, baseball pretty much came first, and we wrote each other mushy poems. I never expected it, nor did she, but that's often the way things turn out. INT.   MARK'S PLACE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rod shows Father Brendan into Mark's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was quite something. What do you propose to do for an encore?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yep, I almost found out the big secret. But here I am, back with the living. If there is another place, then I think they took one look at me and decided to throw me back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And welcome back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And thank you for coming to visit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know it's been awhile since we talked about this... About Cheryl. At the time, you seemed to feel so badly about her... or about it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I no longer feel like that. Father Brendan is rather taken by surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? That's good to hear. In the end, you're glad that you did it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I am. In fact, at this point in time, I feel very blessed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blessed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, blessed. They put me on this new anti-depressant and now I can really see life from the cup half full rather than cup half empty point of view. Father Brendan looks truly amazed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It takes about six weeks to kick in, but when it does, you can really tell the difference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, that's great. Mark grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm pulling your leg, Father. I'm not on drugs. I have a girlfriend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're kidding me. A real girlfriend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very real girlfriend. She adores me. She'll do anything for me. And I can get pretty kinky sometimes, believe you me. Her name is Susan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm flabbergasted. Is she pretty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sure is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has she got a sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a matter of fact...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm kidding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, you're not. Anyway, we're starting a publishing company together. Father Brendan smiles and shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here I was, all prepared to offer comfort to the forlorn - that's supposed to be my specialty - and now I can just throw away that little speech.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no. Please make the little speech. I'd love to hear it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . Father Brendan sits in a chair next to Mark's iron lung.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Okay, but I'll try and keep it short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't make it too short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, fine. Here goes. The meaning of love. Love is a journey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mark laughs. 163A   OMITTED                                                 163A EXT. MARK'S PLACE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. That's all of I've got. I told you it's short. Love is a journey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Father Brendan lets himself out and walks back the way he came. There is definitely a smile on his face. INT.      MARK'S PLACE.     NIGHT 165                                                                165 Mark also has a smile on his face as he lies awake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EXT.   CHERYL'S PLACE.       DAY 166                                                                166 Josh saunters out to the mail box. He retrieves the mail, sifts through it and pauses over a letter. He is tempted to open it, but thinks better of it. EXT.   CHERYL'S BACKYARD.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Actually, I was on drugs, I was taking anti-depressants and they were helping a bit. At least I was able to see the cup-of-life metaphor as a useful tool. Of course, the two halves were never even. Not in my case, that's for sure. Look at all the years of unendurable crap I've had to put up with. That fills most of the cup. But in the little bit that's left, what do I have to show for myself? Journalism? Poetry? At the very least, three beautiful women who all loved me and will all show up at my funeral.
dialogue.name: dialogue
